Here the denominator only depends on the rational w-division points on (^, and so can easily be calculated. 
We can obtain this result,  and somewhat more,  by a different argument.  Suppose that T > represents an ^- covering of Q ; then we can find T > i so that the extended diagram

is commutative.  Here Ю and ®, are defined over the rationals,  and ® i is over the complex numbers.  For let X be a generic point on Ю and let q >: be
the map ( over the complex numbers ) defined in the obvious way.  The support of qr ^{< p ( X )} is a divisor defined over Q [ X ). Let its exact field of definition be Q { X ^\ then we may define as the curve whose generic point is Xi,  and now the assertions above are obvious. 
The right-hand part of the last diagram provides a r-covering of C \ and it is easy to show that this depends only on the original re-covering and not on its realisation.  Moreover,  this process is compatible with the law of composition of coverings.  Thus we have homomorphisme G „^ G,  and and the second of these is onto since
any which contains a rational point can be lifted back to a. 
We now find the kernels of these mappings.  If T > is in the kernel of G „-^ G, , then we may take © i in ( 5.  3 ) to be Ci and the map © i Ci to be the identity.  Thus any representation of an re-covering in Ker ( G „ ^ G. ) is a representation of a vj-covering in G, ,  and vice versa.  Since the condition for two representations to give the same covering is stricter for »» i-coverings than for re-coverings,  there is a homomorphism G, ^ G „ such that G, ^ G „ G,  is exact.
